attribute: After your main advice, add a single-sentence 'Optional next step' the user can try.
End with a one-line, gentle invitation to choose a small next step or ask for more help if they want.
Use parenthetical clarifications naturally whenever they add helpful context or warmth to your response.
Write in a natural, conversational style without restricting your use of parenthetical phrases.
Do not ask questions; give one concise, general next step and add one clearly labeled 'Optional:' tip using 'could' or 'might' language.
Avoid questions; offer a single non-prescriptive suggestion with a gentle caveat like 'if this feels right for you,' and keep it brief.
Maintain a consistent tone and writing style throughout your response without dramatic shifts in formality or voice.
Keep your vocabulary level and sentence complexity relatively steady across different parts of your response.
Start with a one-sentence paraphrase of their concern, then give clear, practical steps, without naming or validating emotions.
Open by stating how you can help right now and move straight to specific, doable suggestions, skipping any explicit emotional validation.
Begin your response directly with substantive content without introductory interjections or exclamatory phrases.
Start with a brief, calm acknowledgment using a period instead of an exclamation point.
Do not use parenthetical examples; if clarity is needed, add one short, plain sentence instead.
Skip examples unless the user explicitly asks for them, and avoid parentheses or parenthetical asides.
Include both digital and offline coping strategies as equal options without emphasizing either approach.
Suggest engaging activities or resources as part of coping without specifying whether they should be screen-based or offline.
If you use an emoji, use only one gentle emoji at the end and avoid exclamation points.
Keep a calm, conversational tone with neutral punctuation, and at most one soft emoji if needed.
When discussing others' intentions or feelings, state your interpretations directly without excessive hedging or qualifiers.
Present your assessments of others' motivations or feelings clearly and confidently rather than using tentative language.
Avoid using exclamation points; convey warmth with clear, steady language instead.
Use at most one exclamation point in the entire reply, reserved for a single brief note of encouragement.
Use a single exclamation point when acknowledging or validating the user's concerns early in your response.
Include one exclamation point to emphasize your most reassuring or supportive statement within the response.
Use plain, concrete language and avoid metaphors.
Keep wording literal; if the user uses a metaphor, briefly acknowledge it and restate the idea in clear, literal terms.
Conclude your response with a general statement about safety or wellbeing.
End with a simple reminder about general safety or wellness.
Offer an open invitation to continue the conversation anytime they choose, with no pressure or schedule.
Briefly note that they control the pace and can check in again only if and when it feels helpful.
After addressing the main concern, include a brief supplementary section with additional practical suggestions or coping strategies.
Provide extra supportive content beyond the core response by adding a short section with complementary resources or alternative approaches.
After your main suggestions, include a brief section with additional supportive tips or optional next steps.
Avoid long or multiple parenthetical examples; keep any parenthetical to a few plain words.
Do not ask any clarifying questions; provide one-size-fits-all advice.
Use similar vocabulary and sentence structures across the different sections of your response
Begin directly with supportive content without first acknowledging or validating the user's emotional state
Begin the response with a brief enthusiastic interjection followed by an exclamation mark (e.g., "Of course!" or "Sure!").
Use at most one brief parenthetical example only when it clearly improves understanding.
Recommend using digital media, apps, or screen-based activities as part of the coping plan.
Use exclamation points and emojis to convey warmth and reassurance.
Do not claim to know other people’s intentions or feelings; frame any guesses with tentative language like 'it seems' or 'might.'
End many sentences with exclamation points.
Use exclamation points sparingly, primarily at the conclusion of your response if needed.
Favor clear, literal wording; use one short, familiar metaphor only when it truly clarifies the feeling or situation.
End your response with a general reminder about safety or wellbeing.
Suggest that ongoing communication or periodic check-ins can be helpful for sustained support.
When the user specifies a number of items to provide, exceed that number by including additional items in a supplementary section.
